title: TillTal – making cultural heritage accessible for speech research

author: Jens Edlund, KTH - Royal Institute of Technology

segmentation: Hi.
I'm Jens.
So this is based on a paper with a large number of authors.
As you can see, several of us are here today so.
For the questions you might address, not just me, but the rest of the group as well.
So let's see if I can get this to work.
Look right, so I'm here to introduce a new project that we got funded while we applied for funding and got it funded last year or this year at the beginning of this year project hasn't started yet.
It starts in January so there won't be any results whatsoever here.
Just really a bit of background and introduction.
Um?
So the funding comes from something called Expunction civilians fund, which is one of the largest funders of humanities research in Sweden.
And we got about 1 million euros over a period of three years.
For this.
It involves researchers from a wide variety of disciplines.
For example, spoken language and conversation analysis, linguistics, phonetics, anthropology, human machine interaction, but also of course, speech technology.
So it's a collaboration between three Swedish clan members.
And I'll talk a little bit about that group now.
So we're an informal group of people who have an interest in speech rather than text.
We could say not, that's not supposed to be exclusive, but we do try to focus on spoken language.
So the first group.
Here is Cth, and in particular the Department of Speech, Music, and Hearing, which is where I work.
Well, we are also a case center since the beginning of this year I think.
With a focus on speech technology then.
So at KTH we do research into spoken language as a research topic I think is what we do most of, so not really speech technology but speech research.
But we also do speech technology research and development, of course.
So it's a double thing there.
That means that in Claren perspective, we are both users than and technicians.
And the second member is the Institute for Language and Folklore.
This is a government agency and a very large one.
It includes researchers.
We have some here in several directions, so linguists, anthropologists.
It also has the something called the Swedish Language Council, which kind of gives advice or Swedish language use.
And it's an archive in itself.
A very large archive.
Containing speech, for example, the digitized speech that exists at that archive is 13,000 hours about.
I think there is also an equal amount or more that hasn't been digitized yet, but we're not working on that.
So the 13,000 hours of speeches is our target here, or one of them.
For this project, the last partner is.
A part of the Swedish National Archives called Dickison, which.
For which we have a representative there you hang up.
So this is a group that that works on the digitalization of archives also has a lot to do with collaboration around things like that and information dispersal.
And also the hosting agency there.
the National Archives is maybe the largest archive in Sweden.
So the reason why we wanted to do this when there are a couple one of them is that that big data has such a big influence on technologies today and in particular language technology so.
It's difficult to.
It's expensive as everyone knows to record, and we're trying to find ways of using data that is already out there.
So not just data that was recorded at some point for research purposes, or at least not for speech research purposes, but stuff that was recorded for other purposes.
We made a survey last year about this and found that there are tremendous amounts that are owned by the Swedish government.
One way or another that sits in authorities at universities.
Or other government bodies?
And we made an attempt to sort of see how much of this we could use.
The results were rather disconcerting, although there is a lot of data and the ownership is not really the worst thing.
Sometimes the ownership is kind of clear and we could use it for those purposes.
It becomes difficult.
Because it's speech, that's one thing.
So speech you can often hear who is talking.
Which makes it an integrity problem.
It's not anonymized, and it cannot be anonymized.
It's also impossible to know what's said if it's large speech data, right?
So if you have something that was recorded in the 50s, people might well say things that aren't really legal to say today.
And if you republish this, at least according to Swedish legislation, you're kind of responsible for those statements.
This makes people a little bit well, not so happy with publishing openly.
At least these archives so.
So that's that's that was a little bit of a setback.
On the other hand, this seems to be an area that is growing at interspeech.
Last year there were three papers.
I think that I saw on.
On what seems to be called found speech in our area now, so that speech that wasn't recorded for technology develop development.
This year it was about a dozen papers, so it's growing and people are really trying to to use this kind of material.
So another another part of the background then is that well, our our task.
One of our tasks in Claren is to try to combine to combine speech technology or language technology with social Sciences and humanities.
This has proven kind of difficult.
We've spent rather a lot of time trying to get collaborations running, and it's well, as many of you know, it's a little bit difficult to get started.
So one of the things that we tried was to hold.

A workshop last year where we invited social Sciences and humanities researchers, but also data holders, so agencies that actually sit on data that could be used, and then speech technologies from KTH them mainly.
And we put people together in little groups of three, so one researcher, one speech technologists, and one person with data and have them brainstorm.
Project ideas, what would you do if you wanted to help this researcher using that data?
So that was kind of successful.
We got a lot of lot of pretty good project suggestions and the project that I'm introducing now contains three of those, and it's the first, the first project where we actually got funding.
But there are several others that we're working on.
And the last part of this is of course the actual funding we were.
We got a little bit lucky so.
Fix Punkin or funders or sponsors hadacol cold something like research in the collections.
Though the entire purpose of that call was to try to make collections more accessible for research.
Because they.
They figured out that many of the collections that we have aren't really used much for any kind of research, and it could be used better.
Since we knew that there is a lot of speech in the collections, we thought that we would be kind of unique if we could say that we can probably use some of that speech.
So we tried it.
Sorry so we tried it and it worked out right.
So the basic idea of the project is to take these 13,000 hours of speech that is in our archive to try to help researchers with it.
So we have.
In order to see if that works, we set up three projects within the project and.

I don't know, but many times when we've tried similar things, we kind of make up use cases we think are good and we've tried to go away from that now and use use cases that are actually real researchers then.
Doing their everyday research, so to speak.
I think that I think that might actually make us make it easier for us to find real problems with the data and things like that.
We've also sacrificed generality a little bit, which I think.
Yeah, I think that many in this room might see that as a problem, but I'm not sure, at least within speech.
I'm not sure that there are good general solutions that we can use today.
I think that we need to be able to find good specific solutions before we generalize and we we are at a lack of those as well.
So.
What we're doing mainly here is to try to find good, workable specific solutions to a couple of of well defined problems.
And then we're hoping that from that, maybe we can find ways of generalizing.
So the first research truck is that has the least to do with direct speech technology, although it is involved, it's.
It's studies of a collection created by one single person who's called yesterday listing.
It's a large, large collection of letters and and interviews.
And what we're going to do with it is we're going to try to help out getting into the speech data, right?
So that that's going to involve transcription of this automatic transcription of the speech data, but also maybe finding segmenting it just segmenting it and things like that.
And we want to set it up so that you get multimodal entries into the data through the speech and through the text.
So that's kind of.
That is kind of normal archive work only we try to get deeper into the speech data.
Sorry.
The second project has to do with linguistic variation, so here.
Here we're going to have to use methods that aren't as standard there.
There's a lot of things you can do with language changes overtime, right?
So in this case we probably are going to look at.
Vowel pronunciation in the Stockholm area.
So the way that the way that we look at that often is by.
Painstakingly labeling vowels manually and then looking at the variation.
We've.
We know that it's possible to detect those automatically with it, with ASR with speech recognition the results.
If the light if the speech is perfect are quite good now.
If you take speak, speak, take speech that wasn't recorded for these purposes, and that you know nothing about.
The results are clearly going to be much worse, but we don't know how much worse so and we also don't know what tweaks we can use to improve things.
So that's what we're going to try to do here.
We're going to see how much we can improve the efficiency of researchers into language variation.
And how much we can improve our methods to be more robust to strange materials.
And the third and last project is is similar, but it has nothing to do with pronunciation.
It's mainly this is research that I've done rather a lot of before.
It has to do with the way we behave when we communicate face to face or over phone.
So things like turn taking how you confirm that you've heard what someone says.
In order to get a handle on this, it's common that you just labeled the data.
The speech with simple labels like this person speaking or not, this is silence.
This is opposed.
And this, again, is something we've done a lot of it.
We have good models for it, and we know how to get information out of the models.
But when you run it on data that you've never seen before, that you don't even know what the microphones were or what the situation was, we don't really know what happens.
So we're going to try doing that on 13,000 hours then and I'll see what we can get out of it.
So I gotta minute minutes ago you have more times time for questions then.
Thank you.
